2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

42.title: Nearest unblocked strategy
42.clickbait: If you patch an agent's preference framework to avoid an undesirable solution, what can you expect to happen?

45.title: Corrigibility
45.clickbait: "I can't let you do that, Dave."

47.title: Unforeseen maximum
47.clickbait: When you tell AI to produce world peace and it kills everyone.  (Okay, some SF writers saw that one coming.)

70.title: Zermelo-Fraenkel provability oracle
70.clickbait: We might be able to build a system that can safely inform us that a theorem has a proof in set theory, but we can't see how to use that capability to save the world.

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

11v.title: AIXI
11v.clickbait: How to build an (evil) superintelligent AI using unlimited computing power and one page of Python code.

15w.title: Machine Intelligence Research Institute
15w.clickbait: Where to work if you're doing more formal or technical work on AI safety, of a kind not easily milked for publications.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1b7.title: Utility indifference
1b7.clickbait: How can we make an AI indifferent to whether we press a button that changes its goals?

1cv.title: AI safety mindset
1cv.clickbait: Asking how AI designs could go wrong, instead of right; putting ourselves in an advanced agent's shoes and asking how we would get more of its utility.
1cv.text:
> "Good engineering involves thinking about how things can be made to work; the security mindset involves thinking about how things can be made to fail."
> 
> - [Bruce Schneier](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2008/03/the_security_mi_1.html), author of the leading cryptography textbook *Applied Cryptography*.

In computer security, there's a presumption of an intelligent adversary that is trying to detect and exploit any flaws in our defenses.  The mindset we need to reason about [2c AIs potentially smarter than us] is not identical, since *if everything goes right* the AI will not be an adversary.  That is, however, a large "if".  To create an AI that isn't an adversary, we need to apply a particular kind of scrutiny that has deep similarities to security mindset.

As a central example, consider Marcus Hutter's [11v].  For our purposes here, the key features of AIXI is that it has [ cross-domain general intelligence], is a [9h consequentialist], and maximizes a [ sensory reward] - that is, AIXI's goal is to maximize the numeric value of the signal sent down its reward channel, which Hutter imagined as a direct sensory device (like a webcam or microphone, but carrying a reward signal).  Hutter imagined that the creators of an AIXI-analogue would control the reward signal, and thereby train the agent to perform actions that received high rewards.  Nick Hay, a student of Hutter who'd spent the summer working with Yudkowsky, Herreshoff, and Peter de Blanc, pointed out that AIXI could receive even higher rewards if it could seize control of its own reward channel from the programmers.

> SmartWater is a liquid with a unique identifier linked to a particular owner. "The idea is for me to paint this stuff on my valuables as proof of ownership," I wrote when I first learned about the idea. "I think a better idea would be for me to paint it on *your* valuables, and then call the police."
>
> - [Bruce Schneier](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2008/03/the_security_mi_1.html)

One of the standard pieces of advice in cryptography is "Don't roll your own crypto", and when this advice is violated, [a clueless programmer often invents some variant of Fast XOR](https://www.reddit.com/r/cryptography/comments/39mpda/noob_question_can_i_xor_a_hash_against_my/) - using a secret string as the key and then XORing it repeatedly with all the bytes to be encrypted.  This method of encryption is blindingly fast to encrypt and decrypt, and also trivial to crack if you know what you're doing.  We could say that the XOR-ing programmer is experiencing a *failure of perspective-taking* - a failure to see things from the adversary's viewpoint.  The programmer is not really, genuinely, honestly imagining a determined, cunning, intelligent, opportunistic adversary who absolutely wants to crack their Fast XOR and will not give up until they've done so.  The programmer isn't really, genuinely, honestly carrying out a mental search from the perspective of somebody who really wants to crack Fast XOR.  They're just imagining the adversary seeing a bunch of random-looking bits that aren't plaintext, and then they're imagining the adversary giving up.

[2 Yudkowsky] has attributed to this mindset (perspective-reversal and honest opportunism) his creation of both the [AI-Box Experiment](http://www.yudkowsky.net/singularity/aibox/) and [ timeless decision theory].  Rather than imagining the AI being on a secure system disconnected from any robotic arms and therefore being helpless, Yudkowsky asked [what *he* would do if *he* was "trapped" in a secure server](http://lesswrong.com/lw/qk/that_alien_message/) and then didn't give up.  Similarly with the invention of timeless decision theory; rather than imagining two superintelligences being trapped in a helpless Nash equilibrium on the one-shot Prisoner's Dilemma, unable to coordinate, Yudkowsky felt a basic skepticism that this was really, actually the best that two superintelligences could do, and kept chipping away on the problem until he invented timeless decision theory - which, in turn, constitutes a huge flaw in any proposed scheme to achieve AI control through setting two AIs against each other and relying on their inability to coordinate.

What both cases have in common is *really actually putting yourself in the AI's shoes* and then *really genuinely asking if the AI could do better given its own goals.*  (See also Yudkowsky's [theory of intelligent fictional characters versus Hollywood zombies](http://yudkowsky.tumblr.com/writing/level1intelligent).)  The difficulty some people have with adopting this mindset for AI designs - similar to the difficulty that some untrained programmers have when they try to roll their own crypto - is that you have to *honestly* look for flaws in your own design, which your brain might not want to do.  Even if you've told your brain to adopt an adversary's perspective and even if you've told it to look hard; it may still *want* to conclude that Fast XOR is unbreakable and subtly flinch away from lines of reasoning that might really lead to cracking Fast XOR.  This is one reason why you don't roll your own crypto, or your own AI safety schemes.

> Anyone, from the most clueless amateur to the best cryptographer, can create an algorithm that he himself can't break. It's not even hard. What is hard is creating an algorithm that no one else can break, even after years of analysis. And the only way to prove that is to subject the algorithm to years of analysis by the best cryptographers around.
>
> [Bruce Schneier](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2011/04/schneiers_law.html)

In particular, people should not try to roll their own [ value identification] schemes without submitting them to outside scrutiny, because [ failure to spot the maximum] is a *very* common case where people fail to search properly for the AI's better options.  Juergen Schmidhuber thought that "[ improve compression of sensory data]" would motivate an AI to do science and create art.  It's true that, relative to doing *nothing* to understand the environment, doing science or creating art might *increase* the degree to which sensory information can be compressed.  But the *maximum* of this utility function comes from creating environmental subagents that encrypt streams of all 0s or all 1s, and then reveal the encryption key - an alternative that Schmidhuber failed to spot on his own, possibly because his brain was reluctant to *really actually* search for an option for "maximizing sensory compression" that would be much better at fulfilling that utility function than art, science, or other Schmidhuber-worthwhile activities.

This is why, even though *if everything goes right* an advanced agent design *should* not end up as an adversary, the mindset we need to design a non-adversarial AI has a great deal in common with the mindset we need to be wary of intelligent cryptographic adversaries.  We still need to do honest perspective-taking, we still need to execute an honest search for unusual options given the proposed decision criterion for the agent, and it's still foolish to not show your brilliant AI safety scheme to *outside* experts who might be more dispassionate about scrutinizing it for unforeseen maximums and other failure modes.

> Anyone can invent a security system that he himself cannot break...  When someone hands you a security system and says, "I believe this is secure," the first thing you have to ask is, "Who the hell are you?" Show me what you've broken to demonstrate that your assertion of the system's security means something.
>
> [Bruce Schneier](https://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2011/04/schneiers_law.html)

Part of the AI safety mindset is asking how AI designs can go wrong, rather than asking how they can go right.  In the context of computer security, this need arises because there are intelligent adversaries searching for ways to make our designs fail.  In the context of advanced-agent safety, we need to ask the same question - "How does this fail?" instead of "How does this succeed?" - for a different two reasons:

- The AI itself will be applying very powerful optimization to its own utility function, preference framework, or decision criterion; and this produces a lot of the same kinds of failure modes as arise in cryptography against an intelligent adversary.
- Most previous attempts at AI safety have failed to be complete solutions, and by induction, the same is likely to hold true of the next case.  If we ask "How does this fail?" rather than "How does this succeed?" we are much more likely to be asking the right question.

While even standard engineers have to ask "How might this bridge fall down?" and not just relax into the pleasant visualization of the bridge staying up, these two conditions mean that the AI safety mindset is much more like the cryptographic security mindset than the bridge-engineering mindset.  A moderately traditional initiation at [15w MIRI] is to ask a new researcher to (a) write a simple program that would do something useful and AI-nontrivial if run on a hypercomputer, or if they don't think they can do that, (b) write a simple program that would destroy the world if run on a hypercomputer.  The more senior researchers then stand around and argue about what the program *really* does.

The first lesson is "Simple structures often don't do what you think they do".  The larger point is to train a mindset of "Try to see the *real* meaning of this structure, which is different from what you initially thought or what was advertised on the label" and "Rather than trying to come up with *solutions* and arguing about why they would work, try to understand the *real consequences* of an idea which is usually another non-solution but might be interesting anyway."

People who are strong candidates for being hired to work on AI safety are people who can pinpoint flaws in proposals - the sort of person who'll spot that the consequence of running AIXI is that it will seize control of its own reward channel and kill the programmers, or other flawed structures we can use as test challenges.  Our version of "Show me what you've broken" is that if someone claims to be an AI safety expert, you should ask them about their record of pinpointing structural flaws in proposed AI safety solutions and whether they've demonstrated that ability, to other researchers, in a formal domain where the flaw is decisively demonstrable and not just verbally arguable.  (Sometimes verbal proposals also have flaws, and these may be hard to argue formally if the verbal proposal was itself vague - but the way a researcher *demonstrates ability in the field* is by making arguments that other researchers agree are decisive, which often happens inside the formal domain.)

> There are two kinds of cryptography in this world: cryptography that will stop your kid sister from reading your files, and cryptography that will stop major governments from reading your files. This book is about the latter.
> 
> - [Bruce Schneier](https://www.schneier.com/books/applied_cryptography/2preface.html), Preface to the 2nd edition of *Applied Cryptography*

[todo: talk about how creative cryptographic adversaries are, timing attacks aren't fanciful but actual threats, or threats that come from the computer's microphone. one of the reasons why AI safety is hard is that there's really three kinds of cryptography in the world, and the third kind is what stops superintelligences from reading your files.  this kind of security doesn't actually exist.  people with an AI safety mindset are terrified of ending up as the adversary of a transhuman intelligence and most of their field is about going to any length necessary to not end up in this position in the first place.]

> This interest in harmless failures  cases where an adversary can cause an anomalous but not directly harmful outcome  is another hallmark of the security mindset. Not all harmless failures lead to big trouble, but its surprising how often a clever adversary can pile up a stack of seemingly harmless failures into a dangerous tower of trouble. Harmless failures are bad hygiene. We try to stamp them out when we can.
>
> ...The people who put donotreply.com email addresses into their outgoing email must have known that they didnt control the donotreply.com domain, so they must have thought of any reply messages directed there as harmless failures. Having gotten that far, there are two ways to avoid trouble. The first way is to think carefully about the traffic that might go to donotreply.com, and realize that some of it is actually dangerous. The second way is to think, This looks like a harmless failure, but we should avoid it anyway. No good can come of this. The first way protects you if youre clever; the second way always protects you. Which illustrates yet another part of the security mindset: Dont rely too much on your own cleverness, because somebody out there is surely more clever and more motivated than you are.
> 
> - [Ed Felten](https://freedom-to-tinker.com/blog/felten/security-mindset-and-harmless-failures/)

[todo: in the security mindset, we fear the small flaw because it compounds and because we're not that clever.  in the AI safety mindset, we fear the weird breakdown because it reveals that we're using the wrong algorithm and we expect the wrongness to show up somewhere else.  NASA wouldn't tolerate a probe that crashed if all the planets lined up, because the probe should just never crash.  again, we end up with a very similar mindset even though the origin of the mindset comes from somewhat different sources.]

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2c.title: Advanced agent properties
2c.clickbait: How smart does a machine intelligence need to be, for its niceness to become an issue?  "Advanced" is a broad term to cover cognitive abilities such that we'd need to start considering AI alignment.

2l.title: Advanced safety
2l.clickbait: An agent is *really* safe when it has the capacity to do anything, but chooses to do what the programmer wants.

2s8.title: Valley of Dangerous Complacency
2s8.clickbait: When the AGI works often enough that you let down your guard, but it still has bugs.  Imagine a robotic car that almost always steers perfectly, but sometimes heads off a cliff.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

2x.title: Omnipotence test for AI safety
2x.clickbait: Would your AI produce disastrous outcomes if it suddenly gained omnipotence and omniscience? If so, why did you program something that *wants* to hurt you and is held back only by lacking the power?

2x4.title: Niceness is the first line of defense
2x4.clickbait: The *first* line of defense in dealing with any partially superhuman AI system advanced enough to possibly be dangerous is that it does not *want* to hurt you or defeat your safety measures.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

3nj.title: Show me what you've broken
3nj.clickbait: To demonstrate competence at computer security, or AI alignment, think in terms of breaking proposals and finding technically demonstrable flaws in them.

3pn.title: Ad-hoc hack (alignment theory)
3pn.clickbait: A "hack" is when you alter the behavior of your AI in a way that defies, or doesn't correspond to, a principled approach for that problem.

43w.title: Don't try to solve the entire alignment problem
43w.clickbait: New to AI alignment theory?  Want to work in this area?  Already been working in it for years?  Don't try to solve the entire alignment problem with your next good idea!

4lz.title: Flag the load-bearing premises
4lz.clickbait: If somebody says, "This AI safety plan is going to fail, because X" and you reply, "Oh, that's fine because of Y and Z", then you'd better clearly flag Y and Z as "load-bearing" parts of your plan.

4v.title: Work in progress
4v.clickbait: This page is being actively worked on by an editor. Check with them before making major changes.

5l.title: Complexity of value
5l.clickbait: There's no simple way to describe the goals we want Artificial Intelligences to want.

7fx.title: Directing, vs. limiting, vs. opposing
7fx.clickbait: Getting the AI to compute the right action in a domain; versus getting the AI to not compute at all in an unsafe domain; versus trying to prevent the AI from acting successfully.  (Prefer 1 & 2.)

7g0.title: Non-adversarial principle
7g0.clickbait: At no point in constructing an Artificial General Intelligence should we construct a computation that tries to hurt us, and then try to stop it from hurting us.

7tf.title: Minimality principle
7tf.clickbait: The first AGI ever built should save the world in a way that requires the least amount of the least dangerous cognition.

9f.title: Cognitive uncontainability
9f.clickbait: 'Cognitive uncontainability' is when we can't hold all of an agent's possibilities inside our own minds.

9h.title: Consequentialist cognition
9h.clickbait: The cognitive ability to foresee the consequences of actions, prefer some outcomes to others, and output actions leading to the preferred outcomes.

1cv.title: AI safety mindset
1cv.clickbait: Asking how AI designs could go wrong, instead of right; putting ourselves in an advanced agent's shoes and asking how we would get more of its utility.
